newsitem.title: FRANCE: De Gaulle stamp plan raises Canadian hackles.
newsitem.headline: De Gaulle stamp plan raises Canadian hackles.

text.p: France said on Wednesday it had made no final decision on issuing a postage stamp commemorating president Charles de Gaulle's fiery 1967 visit to Quebec, an idea which has prompted an official protest from Ottawa.

De Gaulle cheered Quebec separatists but outraged the federal Canadian government with an impassioned Montreal speech supporting the province's independence with the cry "Vive le Quebec libre" (Long live a free Quebec).
He had to curtail his visit to Canada because of the furore caused by the speech.
Asked about reported plans for the stamp, Foreign Ministry spokesman Jacques Rummelhardt told reporters: "The Canadian authorities have expressed their concern.
"This is a plan. If it is a plan that means no decision has been taken," he said, adding that France wanted relations with Ottawa to be as warm as possible.

De Gaulle's call is credited with having boosted separatist sentiments in Quebec just as Canada was celebrating its centennial, and it remains a sore point in diplomatic relations between Canada and France.
